text.sentence: Energy | Americas Integrated Oil twenty five January two thousand sixteen

Despite the price of oil declining nearly fifty percent in two thousand fifteen, and an estimated cash burn of dollar five.five dollar six. billion over the same period, ConocoPhillips has maintained one of the industry's most generous dividend payouts.
Not surprisingly, with each additional leg down in the price of oil, the market has raised concerns about the company's dividend sustainability.
This concern has intensified over the last two months as global oil prices have collapsed to below dollar thirty.
Equity Research View: Overweight We believe there is a slightly more than fifty percent probability COP will cut its dividend over the next couple of quarters.
We also believe that COP should act when it reports fourQfifteen results in early February and that it should cut the dividend by at least seventy five percent .

Although we think the shares would face short term pressure due to the dividend cut, they should stabilize after a couple of weeks and begin to outperform other E and P companies for the rest of the downturn.

More importantly, we believe a significant dividend cut would dramatically improve the company's long term competitive position as COP would become one of the sector's lowest breakeven cost producers.

Credit Research View: Underweight At current commodity prices, COP's earnings and cash flow are pressured, and we believe that this, in combination with continued negative free cash flow, will put pressure on COP's credit metrics such that its current ratings are at significant risk.
Ultimately, we think that a dividend reduction is a necessary, but not necessarily sufficient, step for the company to try to salvage its single A status.

We have an Underweight rating on COP, given our view that the credit ratings could eventually migrate below single A, triggering selling from some bondholders and repricing the credit in line with BBB E and P issuers during what is a risk off market for commodity producers.

Reasonable underlying decline rate and production outlook raise investors' confidence level that the company's strategic transition could work if executed successfully.
We believe the company could become operationally self funded by two thousand seventeen/two thousand eighteen under a dollar one hundred/bl Brent oil environment.
Our upside case assumes a long term Brent price deck of dollar ninety/bl in our NAV analysis from our current assumption of dollar eighty dollar ninety/bl Brent.
Our downside scenario assumes a long term oil price deck of dollar fifty five/bl in our NAV analysis from our current assumption of dollar eighty dollar ninety/bl Brent.

hundred twenty six.one thousand eight hundred eighty four paul.cheng at barclays dot com BCI, US Alex Letko one.two
hundred twenty six.seven thousand six hundred four alex.letko at barclays dot com BCI, US Moses Sutton one.two

Despite the price of oil declining nearly fifty percent in two thousand fifteen, and an estimated cash burn of dollar five.five dollar six. billion over the same period, ConocoPhillips has maintained one of the industry's most generous dividend payouts.
Management has repeatedly demonstrated its commitment to the current policy, raising the dividend by a penny to dollar .seventy
percent compared to XOM at three.eight percent and CVX at five.three percent .
Not surprisingly, every time oil prices have taken another leg down, the market has raised concerns about the company's ability to fund its very large dividend commitment.
This concern has intensified over the last two months as global oil prices have sunk to below dollar thirty.
In our opinion, to fully address the issue, we need to answer the following set of questions:
If oil prices average dollar thirty five for the next two years, by how much would COP need to cut the dividend to live within this limit?
Our short answer to the above questions is that we believe there is a slightly more than fifty percent probability that COP will cut its dividend over the next couple of quarters.
We also believe COP should act when the company reports fourQfifteen results in early February and that it should reduce the dividend by at least seventy five percent .

Although we think the shares would face short term pressure due to the dividend cut, they should stabilize after a couple of weeks and begin to outperform other E and P companies for the rest of the downturn.

More importantly, we believe a significant dividend cut would dramatically improve the company's long term competitive position as COP would become one of the sector's lowest breakeven cost producers.

Its improved flexibility would allow the company to grow production, cash flow and the dividend on a sustainable basis from the new baseline, even at oil prices as low as dollar forty five dollar fifty.
to the options market, investors are currently expecting an average dividend of dollar .forty
If market expectations for a dividend cut were nil, then the downside risk of surprising the market would be far greater.
As there is clearly some expectation of a cut priced in, the inevitable blow to the stock price would not be as severe.
But, is an expectation of a thirty four percent cut enough?

It is a start, but as discussed below, we think the cut should be far greater in magnitude somewhere in the area of seventy five percent and therefore management would probably feel more comfortable if expectations were lower.
Although management has never publicly addressed this question, we think the answer is likely `no', particularly under the current depressed and uncertain market environment.
While the absolute funding cost difference between BBB+ and A is
Barclays | ConocoPhillips currently not huge, we believe it is a slippery slope and would put the company in a potentially difficult position if the oil market does not recover quickly.
We do not believe management and the Board would be willing to take such a risk.

According to our colleague Harry Mateer, Barclays' high grade energy credit analyst, the risk of COP being downgraded to BBB+ or lower is real and present if the dividend payout is maintained at the current level and prices do not recover.
Please refer to Harry Mateer's section of this report for more detail.
We think the cut should be around seventy five percent from COP's current dividend commitment of dollar three.seven billion in two thousand sixteen.

Based on our current two thousand sixteen Brent oil price assumption of dollar forty six, capex of dollar seven.seven billion and asset sales of dollar four hundred million, COP will run a free cash flow deficit of around dollar four. billion this year.
However, at the future strip of around dollar thirty two, and even after lowering capex to the sustaining level of dollar six.
dollar six.five billion, we estimate the company would burn around ~ dollar five.five billion in cash.
We do not doubt the company's ability to withstand one year of low dollar thirty oil, but anything beyond that is dangerous territory and would eventually force COP to act drastically.

Because we do not believe that a BBB+ or lower credit rating would be acceptable to the Board or management, we estimate that a seventy five percent dividend cut to around dollar nine hundred million would leave COP with a more manageable free cash flow deficit of around dollar two.eight billion under the low oil price scenario.
hit to the stock price would likely be significant, especially given certain shareholders have dividend mandates and may be forced to sell.
Subsequently, however, we think the shares could recover if the dividend were cut enough to eliminate concerns that the company could manage in a low oil price environment for two three years.

On the other hand, the shares are likely to remain under pressure if the dividend is not trimmed sufficiently, and concerns will persist over the company's ability to maintain its credit rating and whether the dividend would have to be further reduced in the future.

We think a sufficient cut would actually allow COP to outperform other E and P names for the rest of the downturn and beyond because COP would become one of the sector's lowest risk names within the sector.
As a recent example, we look at how Husky Energy performed after announcing their dividend suspension on one/nineteen/sixteen, and their stock dividend at the end of threeQfifteen.
After initially dipping fourteen percent in the morning on one/twenty/sixteen, the stock finished down three.three

On the other hand, after swapping its cash dividend for a stock dividend at the end of threeQfifteen, HSE was down about thirty three percent through one/nineteen/sixteen compared to the Canadian average down only sixteen percent .
While the stock dividend was a milder initial jolt to investors, it failed to completely remove concerns of whether the company could manage in a low oil price environment.
However, once the dividend was fully removed and the concerns were more fully addressed, the company's shares fared less poorly.
We estimate that with a seventy five percent dividend cut and capex at the sustaining level of dollar six.
dollar six.five billion, COP could be cash flow neutral at dollar forty five dollar fifty Brent, a proposition that few E and P companies could match.

As oil prices recover, this reset would allow COP to allocate capital to growth opportunities and, given it has probably the best unconventional resource portfolio of any major oil company, we think COP could grow production at two three percent per year even at dollar fifty dollar sixty oil.
From the new, lower dividend base, we think this would allow it to grow the dividend
Barclays | ConocoPhillips consistently going forward, at four percent five percent per year, while at the same time reducing the share count by buying back stock.
The production, cash flow and dividend growth rate could be substantially higher if oil prices average over dollar eighty per barrel over the next ten years.
More importantly, the new financial and operating flexibility will be among the best in the E and P sector.
In our view, the new value proposition would be more superior than prior, since it would not be based on dollar one hundred oil price.

Based on our above analysis, we conclude that there is a more than fifty percent probability the company will cut the dividend in oneHsixteen, and we think management should act when it reports fourQfifteen results in early February.

Although the company continued to insistently defend its dividend policy on its December budget conference call, the global oil market has since fallen by more than dollar fifteen/b in less than two months, with the two thousand sixteen and two thousand seventeen future strips averaging less than dollar thirty five.

The pace and magnitude of the price decline has caught even the most seasoned industry observers off guard, but it has in turn offered an excellent window for COP to press the reset button on its dividend policy, in our opinion.
Critically, we think that by biting the bullet now, COP would at least be doing so while it still has a choice, and thus greater financial flexibility to carry it out.

Should the company forego the current opportunity, and should the oil market remain depressed, it could be forced into cutting the dividend at a point where it has zero optionality and the long term damage to the company would be more severe.
Equally important, we believe a significant dividend cut would actually improve the company's long term competitive position.
COP would become one of the sector's lowest breakeven cost and highest free cash flow producers.

From this new base line, we estimate the company could grow production by two three percent while increasing the dividend by four five percent p.a. even within a dollar fifty dollar sixty oil price environment.
High Grade Credit Research Harry Mateer * +one two hundred twelve four hundred twelve seven thousand nine hundred three harry.mateer
at barclays dot com BCI, US Greggory Price, CFA* +one two hundred twelve four hundred twelve seven thousand nine hundred five greggory.price

COP is rated Atwo, A, and A at Moody's, S and P, and Fitch, respectively, with S and P and Fitch maintaining negative outlooks on the credit while Moody's recently placed the entire E and P sector on review for downgrade .

At current commodity prices, earnings and cash flow are pressured, and we believe that this, in combination with continued negative free cash flow, will put pressure on the company's credit metrics such that its current ratings are at significant risk.
Ultimately, we think that a dividend reduction is a necessary, but not necessarily sufficient, step for the company to try to salvage its single A status.

Although rating agencies take a multi year view when it comes to assessing their credit ratings, we note that price assumptions for two thousand sixteen and beyond continue to fall and will only increase the likelihood of downgrades across the E and P sector.

COP benefits from significant size and scale, which has historically afforded it a premium versus other issuers, even when they have superior leverage metrics, but we think that the agencies will be placing greater weight on cash flow metrics as margins have deteriorated.

Moody's currently indicates a downside threshold for a one notch downgrade to Athree of twenty percent retained cash flow to debt, while S and P would be likely to cut its rating if FFO to debt falls below thirty percent .

As seen in Figure one, we estimate that it is unlikely for COP to meet the agencies' requirements in two thousand sixteen under any of our scenarios, including those in which the company eliminates its dividend entirely.
Given that Moody's currently has the lowest price deck, we are using those prices for our rating agency case scenario .
percent in the best ratings case, we think that it is possible for COP to fall out of the single A category.

Because the agencies tend to move cautiously when it comes to ratings downgrades, our base case expectation is that COP will fall to low A in the near term, with further downside ratings risk later in two thousand sixteen if the oil price is sustained below dollar forty/bbl.
Away from credit ratings, we think that our leverage estimates imply that management needs to act with urgency.
Our unadjusted net debt/EBITDA estimates range from five.eightx to over tenx, but are too high regardless in a sector that has historically been valued at roughly sixx cash flow.

Notwithstanding the potential for oil prices eventually to move higher, we think that credit markets are skeptical about extending capital to companies that are highly leveraged on a spot commodity price deck, even for an issuer as large as COP.

At present, COP has a dollar forty fivebn market cap, but we think that the longer management waits before taking decisive action, the more likely that not only a dividend cut, but also a potential capital raise, will be required to strengthen the capital structure.

We have an Underweight rating on COP, given our view that the credit ratings could eventually migrate below single A, triggering selling from some bondholders and repricing the credit in line with BBB E and P issuers during what is a risk off market for commodity producers.

We acknowledge that COP's size provides it with options that other companies may not have, such as non cash flowing assets that could be monetized and facilitate deleveraging, but we also see risk that management's refusal so far to consider a dividend cut might leave the balance sheet in worse shape before the company takes action.

Although we think that a dividend reduction is likely to spur some spread tightening, we continue to think that bonds and CDS are mispriced for a company that could be around sixx leveraged even with a full dividend cut.
Barclays | ConocoPhillips FIGURE one COP Sensitivity to Various Commodity Prices

Explanation of the Barclays Research Sector Rating System Overweight : For sectors rated against the Barclays U.S. Credit Index, the Barclays Pan European Credit Index, the Barclays EM Asia USD High Grade Credit Index or the Barclays EM USD Corporate and Quasi Sovereign Index, the analyst expects the six month excess return of the sector to exceed the six month excess return of the relevant index.

For sectors rated against the Barclays U.S. High Yield two percent Issuer Capped Credit Index, the Barclays Pan European High Yield three percent Issuer Capped Credit Index excluding Financials, the Barclays Pan European High Yield Finance Index or the Barclays EM Asia USD High Yield Corporate Credit Index, the analyst expects the six month total return of the sector to exceed the six month total return of the relevant index.

Market Weight : For sectors rated against the Barclays U.S. Credit Index, the Barclays Pan European Credit Index, the Barclays EM Asia USD High Grade Credit Index or the Barclays EM USD Corporate and Quasi Sovereign Index, the analyst expects the six month excess return of the sector to be in line with the six month excess return of the relevant index.

For sectors rated against the Barclays U.S. High Yield two percent Issuer Capped Credit Index, the Barclays Pan European High Yield three percent Issuer Capped Credit Index excluding Financials, the Barclays Pan European High Yield Finance Index or the Barclays EM Asia USD High Yield Corporate Credit Index, the analyst expects the six month total return of the sector to be in line with the six month total return of the relevant index.

Underweight : For sectors rated against the Barclays U.S. Credit Index, the Barclays Pan European Credit Index, the Barclays EM Asia USD High Grade Credit Index or the Barclays EM USD Corporate and Quasi Sovereign Index, the analyst expects the six month excess return of the sector to be less than the six month excess return of the relevant index.

For sectors rated against the Barclays U.S. High Yield two percent Issuer Capped Credit Index, the Barclays Pan European High Yield three percent Issuer Capped Credit Index excluding Financials, the Barclays Pan European High Yield Finance Index or the Barclays EM Asia USD High Yield Corporate Credit Index, the analyst expects the six month total return of the sector to be less than the six month total return of the relevant index.
Sector definitions: Sectors in U.S. High Grade Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Barclays U.S. Credit Index and are rated against the Barclays U.S. Credit Index.

Sectors in U.S. High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Barclays U.S. High Yield two percent Issuer Capped Credit Index and are rated against the Barclays U.S. High Yield two percent Issuer Capped Credit Index.
Sectors in European High Grade Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Barclays Pan European Credit Index and are rated against the Barclays Pan European Credit Index.

Sectors in Industrials and Utilities in European High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Barclays Pan European High Yield three percent Issuer Capped Credit Index excluding Financials and are rated against the Barclays Pan European High Yield three percent Issuer Capped Credit twenty five January two thousand sixteen nine

Sectors in Financials in European High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Barclays Pan European High Yield Finance Index and are rated against the Barclays Pan European High Yield Finance Index.
Sectors in Asia High Grade Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Barclays EM Asia USD High Grade Credit Index.
Sectors in Asia High Yield Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Barclays EM Asia USD High Yield Corporate Credit Index.
Sectors in EEMEA and Latin America Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Barclays EM USD Corporate and Quasi Sovereign Index.
These sectors may contain both High Grade and High Yield issuers.
To view sector definitions and monthly sector returns for Asia, EEMEA and Latin https://live.barcap
dot com /go/RSL/servlets/dv.search?pubType=four thousand five hundred eleven and contentType=latest on Barclays Live.

Explanation of the Barclays Research Credit Rating System For all High Grade issuers covered in the US, Europe or Asia, and for all issuers in Latin America and EEMEA, the credit rating system is based on the analyst's view of the expected excess return over a six month period of the issuer's index eligible corporate debt securities* relative to the expected excess return of the relevant sector, as specified on the report.
Overweight : The analyst expects the six month excess return of the issuer's index eligible corporate debt securities to exceed the sixmonth expected excess return of the relevant sector.

Market Weight : The analyst expects the six month excess return of the issuer's index eligible corporate debt securities to be in line with the six month expected excess return of the relevant sector.
Underweight : The analyst expects the six month excess return of the issuer's index eligible corporate debt securities to be less than the sixmonth expected excess return of the relevant sector.

Rating Suspended : The rating has been suspended temporarily due to market events that make coverage impracticable or to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies in certain circumstances including where the Investment Bank of Barclays Bank PLC is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving the company.
Coverage Suspended : Coverage of this issuer has been temporarily suspended.
Not Covered : Barclays' fundamental credit research team does not provide formal, continuous coverage of this issuer and has not assigned a rating to the issuer or its debt securities.

Any analysis, opinion or trade recommendation provided on a Not Covered issuer or its debt securities is valid only as of the publication date of this report and there should be no expectation that additional reports relating to the Not Covered issuer or its debt securities will be published thereafter.

For all High Yield issuers, the credit rating system is based on the analyst's view of the expected total returns over a six month period of the rated debt security relative to the expected total return of the relevant sector, as specified on the report.
Overweight : The analyst expects the six month total return of the debt security subject to this rating to exceed the six month expected total return of the relevant sector.
Market Weight : The analyst expects the six month total return of the debt security subject to this rating to be in line with the six month expected total return of the relevant sector.
Underweight : The analyst expects the six month total return of the rated debt security subject to this rating to be less than the six month expected total return of the relevant sector.

Rating Suspended : The rating has been suspended temporarily due to market events that make coverage impracticable or to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies in certain circumstances including where the Investment Bank of Barclays Bank PLC is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving the company.

For all issuers in South Africa, the credit rating system is based on the analyst's view of the expected total return over a six month period of the issuer's rand denominated fixed rate notes or floating rate notes relative to the South African Credit Fixed Market Index or the South African Credit Floating Market Index, respectively.

Overweight : The analyst expects the six month total returns of the issuer's rand denominated fixed rate notes or floating rate notes to exceed the six month expected total returns the South African Credit Fixed Market Index or the South African Credit Floating Market Index, respectively.

Market Weight : The analyst expects the six month total returns of the issuer's rand denominated fixed rate notes or floating rate notes to be in line with the six month expected total returns the South African Credit Fixed Market Index or the South African Credit Floating Market Index, respectively.. Underweight : The analyst expects the six month total returns of the issuer's rand denominated fixed rate notes or floating rate notes to be below the six month expected total returns the South African Credit Fixed Market Index or the South African Credit Floating Market Index, respectively.. Guide to the Barclays Fundamental Equity Research Rating System: Our coverage analysts use a relative rating system in which they rate stocks as Overweight, Equal Weight or Underweight relative to other companies covered by the analyst or a team of analysts that are deemed to be in the same industry .
In addition to the stock rating, we provide industry views which rate the outlook for the industry coverage universe as Positive, Neutral or Negative .
A rating system using terms such as buy, hold and sell is not the equivalent of our rating system.
Investors should carefully read the entire research report including the definitions of all ratings and not infer its contents from ratings alone.
Stock Rating Overweight The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.
Equal Weight The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelvemonth investment horizon.
Underweight The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.

Rating Suspended The rating and target price have been suspended temporarily due to market events that made coverage impracticable or to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies in certain circumstances including where the Investment Bank of Barclays Bank PLC is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving the company.
Neutral industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.

Exxon Mobil Corp. Imperial Oil Ltd. Petroleo Brasileiro S.A. Distribution of Ratings: Barclays Equity Research has one thousand nine hundred sixty seven companies under coverage.

Guide to the Barclays Research Price Target: Each analyst has a single price target on the stocks that they cover.

The price target represents that analyst's expectation of where the stock will twenty five January two thousand sixteen twelve Chevron Corporation Hess Corp. Murphy Oil Suncor Energy ConocoPhillips Husky Energy, Inc. Petroleo Brasileiro S.A.
Upside/downside scenarios, where provided, represent potential upside/potential downside to each analyst's price target over the same twelve month period.
Top Picks: Barclays Equity Research's Top Picks represent the single best alpha generating investment idea within each industry, taken from among the Overweight rated stocks within that industry.
Barclays Equity Research publishes global and regional Top Picks reports every quarter and analysts may also publish intra quarter changes to their Top Picks, as necessary.
While analysts may highlight other Overweight rated stocks in their published research in addition to their Top Pick, there can only be one Top Pick for each industry.
To view the current list of Top Picks, go to the Top Picks page on Barclays Live .
To see a list of companies that comprise a particular industry coverage universe, please go to http://publicresearch.barclays

Valuation Methodology: Using our net asset valuation framework, we assume a long term Brent and WTI price of dollar sixty five/bl and dollar fifty nine/bl, respectively.
In addition, we assign slightly higher premiums for chemicals and refiners when the company has historically shown higher returns compared to peers.
We also take into account our estimate of expected free cash flow and EV/after tax cash flow analysis in our assessment.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Our earnings estimates are based on Barclays Research's current commodity price assumptions, including oil and gas prices, refining and marketing margins as well as chemical product margins.
Thus, results will be subject to change due to fluctuations in the macro commodity market environment.
